fields.headline: World Book Day event podcasts
fields.bodyText: As part of our World Book Day celebrations, all this week we are welcoming children's authors into the Guardian's Newsroom theatre to talk about their work and answer questions from groups of schoolchildren - their most fervent fans (and, occasionally, harshest critics. One of the authors was asked by a disgruntled small boy, "why do you have so many creatures in your books? It really annoys me"). Today it was the turn of the youngest schoolchildren as a reception class of four and five year olds were treated to author Malachy Doyle reading from his award-winning book The Dancing Tiger and singing and acting along to One, Two, Three O'Leary. He was followed by Ian Whybrow who read and sang from Here Comes Harry with his Bucketful of Dinosaurs. Click here to listen to Malachy Doyle and Ian Whybrow on your computer (MP3; 40mins21, Ian Whybrow comes in at 18mins06), or paste http://blogs.guardian.co.uk/culturevulture/podcast.xml into the Podcasts bit of iTunes or your RSS reader, to subscribe to the Culture Vulture feed and receive all the Vulture's podcasts as they become available. Yesterday's event: Gwyneth Rees and Nick Sharratt A class of 5-7 year olds were entertained with the stories of Gwyneth Rees and the words and pictures of Nick Sharratt, the popular illustrator and picture book creator. Click here to listen to Nick Sharratt on your computer (MP3; 17mins51), or paste http://blogs.guardian.co.uk/culturevulture/podcast.xml into the Podcasts bit of iTunes or your RSS reader, to subscribe to the Culture Vulture feed and receive all the Vulture's podcasts as they become available. Yesterday's event: Cressida Cowell, Paul Stewart and Chris Riddell Kicking off the series are three of the most popular names in children's fiction in the 7-9 age group. First up is Cressida Cowell, the author and illustrator of four books about pirates, including How to be a Pirate, How to Speak Dragonese and How to Train your Dragon. Following her are Paul Stewart and Chris Riddell, the Smartie prize-winning author/illustrator team behind The Edge Chronicles series of books and Fergus Crane.
